summary: Email correspondence between defense attorney Brendan White and an Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding a witness's scheduled grand jury appearance in the Epstein case. The emails discuss travel arrangements, immunity, and reveal that Epstein intends to plead guilty in Florida state court on Monday pursuant to a deferred prosecution agreement.

persons.name: Brendan White
persons.context: Attorney representing a witness (Ms. [redacted]) who is scheduled to testify before the grand jury. He is communicating with the U.S. Attorney's office about travel, immunity, and the impact of Epstein's impending guilty plea.

persons.name: Shawn Ball
persons.context: Assistant U.S. Attorney copied on an email from Brendan White regarding the grand jury appearance and immunity for the witness.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of the investigation. The email states he intends to plead guilty in Florida state court on Monday pursuant to a deferred prosecution agreement.

connections.description: White is not Epstein's attorney, but his communication about Epstein's plea deal directly impacts his client's (a witness's) legal obligations.
Professional correspondence between a defense attorney and an Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding a witness in the Epstein grand jury proceeding.

events.title: Epstein's Planned Guilty Plea
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein intends to plead guilty in Florida state court pursuant to a deferred prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's office.

events.title: Scheduled Grand Jury Testimony
events.description: A witness (Ms. [redacted]) is scheduled to appear before the grand jury to give testimony in the Epstein investigation.

locations: 500 S. Australian Ave, Suite 400, West Palm Beach, FL 33401
keyFacts: The document reveals that as of June 26, 2008, Jeffrey Epstein intended to plead guilty in Florida state court on the upcoming Monday (June 30, 2008) pursuant to a deferred prosecution agreement.
A witness was still scheduled to testify before a grand jury on July 1, 2008, despite the impending plea deal, raising questions about the scope of the state vs. federal investigations.
The U.S. Attorney's office required a written proffer from the witness's attorney regarding her anticipated testimony before considering a grant of immunity.
The correspondence shows coordination between the defense and prosecution regarding witness logistics and legal protections ahead of the grand jury appearance.
